article.title: Chasing the observational signatures of seed black holes at z > 7: candidate statistics

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 depict regarding the formation of light and heavy BH seeds?
choices: Light BH seeds form in a wider range of halo masses compared to heavy BH seeds.
Light and heavy BH seeds form in halos with similar mass ranges, despite forming at different average redshifts.
Heavy BH seeds are predominantly found in halos with masses below 10^7 solar masses.
The average number of light BH seeds formed is significantly lower than the number of heavy BH seeds.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does Figure 2 convey about the evolution of isolated light and heavy seed hosts?
choices: A majority of isolated heavy seed hosts merge with other galaxies within the first 100 Myr.
Isolated light seed hosts remain isolated for a significantly longer period than isolated heavy seed hosts.
The average number of isolated light seed hosts is consistently lower than the number of isolated heavy seed hosts.
The duration of the isolated phase for both light and heavy seed hosts rarely exceeds 200 Myr.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does Figure 3 reveal about the mass distribution of isolated light (ILS) and heavy (IHS) seed BHs over time?
choices: The mass difference between ILS and IHS remains relatively constant from z=16.5 to z=10.
ILS consistently exhibit higher masses compared to IHS at all redshifts shown.
The mass difference between ILS and IHS becomes more pronounced at lower redshifts (e.g., z=10) due to different growth rates.
At z=10, both ILS and IHS primarily occupy the same mass bin, indicating similar mass growth.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this formula represent in the context of the article:  Ð¤(m) x m^-1.35e^(-mch/m)
choices: The Bondi-Hoyle-Lyttleton (BHL) accretion rate formula, determining the rate at which a BH accretes gas.
The Larson initial mass function (IMF), describing the distribution of stellar masses at birth.
The formula for calculating the Eddington luminosity, representing the maximum luminosity a BH can achieve via accretion.
The equation for the critical LW radiation intensity required for the formation of a DCBH.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from Figure 5 regarding the evolution of stellar mass and metallicity in host galaxies of different BH seeds at z < 10?
choices: Galaxies hosting merged heavy seeds (MHS) maintain lower metallicity compared to merged light seed hosts (MLS) and hybrid BH hosts (HBH) at z < 10.
The stellar mass of galaxies hosting different BH seeds diverges significantly at z < 10, indicating continued influence of the seed type.
The differences in stellar mass and metallicity observed at z > 10 between galaxies hosting different seed types persist at z < 10.
At z < 10, galaxies hosting light seeds exclusively merge with other light seed hosts, leading to distinct populations.
